awd_abstract_narration:
Sonia Ryang, professor of anthropology in the University of Iowa, will undertake research on how culture and personality are developed and maintained in totalitarian contexts. Dr. Ryang explores this in the context of North Korea, one of the most reclusive totalitarian regimes in the world. Three specific aims are pursued in this research: (1) to place North Korea in the context of currently existing anthropological knowledge; (2) to render the mechanism that secures the connection between the people and the leader in North Korea intelligible; (3) to explore the concept of agency, with the focus on the concept of self, in North Korea. The research involves multi-lingual, multi-media, and mixed-method approach by comprehensively surveying and analyzing written and audio-visual materials in three languages of Korean, Japanese and English, combined with interviews with North Korean refugees. 

The project will contribute to anthropological and broader social scientific understandings of totalitarianism by exploring the cultural logics that are used to rationalize and sustain it within these societies.  

In contributing to our understanding of a part of the world that we know very little about, a nuclear-armed nation with whom the United States has had over a half-century of hostilities, the project contributes significantly to improving national security. The most famous of the early culture and personality studies in anthropology were watershed studies of Japan during World War II, which were enormously influential to the U.S. Government both during and after the war.

por.por_cntn:
The targeted outcome of this project was two-fold: to situate the study of a totalitarian society (North Korea) within the purview of anthropological knowledge, and to interrogate the self in North Korea, anthropologically, as a key for understanding the cultural logic of this society. North Korea to this day is closed to anthropological research, in that a serious ethnographic fieldwork there would not be possible. Drawing upon past examples mainly produced by the Culture and Personality School scholars, the representative of which is embodied in Chrysanthemum and the Sword by Ruth Benedict, this project examined the parameters of possible anthropological research on North Korea. Published in 1946, Benedict’s book was commissioned by the Office of War Information as part of its study of the enemy during WWII. The Japanese military behavior, unknown hitherto to the West, such as kamikaze suicide sorties that attacked Pearl Harbor, needed to be understood. Unlike her contemporaries, Benedict, however, did not resort to pejorative explanation and labeling of the Japanese. Instead, she used the Culture and Personality method of looking into the native logic and cultural patterns that the Japanese were accustomed to and explained their behavior in connection to the devotion and loyalty that they were taught to have toward their Emperor, which would induce the strong sense of honor if one were to die for Him. Her study, albeit burdened by limitations and problems, provided a convincing explanation of the Japanese cultural logic at the time.

            When trying to think about North Korea anthropologically, Ruth Benedict’s contribution offers a useful point of departure. Just like Japan during WWII, North Korea has been framed and depicted in terms of enemy and evil; just like Japan during WWII, North Korea has been taken as incomprehensible and beyond the Western reason, and; just like Japan during WWII, North Korea is seen as primitive and bizarre. An anthropological study of North Korea is thus burdened doubly by the fact that it is unprecedented and also North Korea is already heavily labeled as evil in the Western public discourse. Although the project has been conceived as anthropological inquiry into a totalitarian society, even the very name “totalitarianism” requires a careful usage when thinking about North Korea, even though the oft-assumed attributes of totalitarianism appear to exist prominently in North Korea: loving image of the dictator; sense of national superiority; the excess of the political as opposed to the economic concerns, and so on. In order to address this study, the project primarily dealt with the native publications, focusing on a mass-volume and long-lasting publication series called Inmindeul sogeseo, among others; published since 1963 and ongoing to this day, this series comprises the essays written by individuals who had direct contact with the Great Leader. The essays are written in formulaic language, which while shifted over decades, captures what one may call the national truth: the truth of the Great Leader’s love, virtue, sagacity, and power, which is tautologously presented and confirmed, over and over again, in diverse incarnations captured by hundreds of essays. What emerges from these essays is a practice that is derived from and at the same time constitutes and reinforces a regime of truth wherein exists the core of the North Korean culture.

            As part of this project, the PI also met with a few North Korean defectors in North America. The data taken in this area does not constitute a major part of the research, since the defector data requires a very careful vetting and using it comes with a risk of ethical as well as intellectual problems. Nevertheless, the meetings were useful in that the textual data was better framed and contextualized based on the interviews. Based on the project, the PI is completing a research monograph.
